issues.title: Client or Server CID
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: The text uses CID, while it would be more accurate in some parts of the text to call out whether this is SCID or DCID.

comments.author: boucadair

issues.title: Comments on the draft
issues.author: tireddy2
issues.body:
(1) Section 4 may also want to discuss a scenario where the client is aware of the network identity (e.g., "example.net").  In this case, the DNS query will be "_cidfi-aware.example.net". 

(2) I suggest removing Appendix A (it has privacy issues, revealing network identity to the server).

(3)Section 5.2, the client could authorize the CIDFI network elements if it has sufficient reputation (e.g., it would work for Mobile Networks, Enterprise networks etc.). It would avoid end-user intervention in certain deployments.

(4) Section 6.2, in the sequence diagram, replace "HTTP" with "HTTPS"

(5) We should explain the Nonce mechanism prevents a passive attacker but not an active attacker. I mean an active attacker not interested in disrupting the QUIC connection but leveraging this mechanism to learn about the network characteristics.

(6) Section 6.3> We should say PKIX validatation of CIDFI network elements. The client uses default system or application PKI trust anchors unless configured otherwise to use explicit trust anchors.

(7) Any specific reason for choosing STUN request instead of STUN indications ?
   We should go with STUN indications as response is not required. Further, STUN requests are re-transmitted by default.

(8) Note: we may want to use [CoAP] for the client->network communication and over the CIDFI-dedicated QUIC stream between the QUIC client and QUIC server. 

Comment> I think you mean use to "to use [CBOR] for the client->network..."

(9)  I don't know if kaippallimalil-tsvwg-media-hdr-wireless will progress. Can we avoid the dependency on kaippallimalil-tsvwg-media-hdr-wireless ?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: outdated

issues.title: See if csig is relevant to this work
issues.author: boucadair

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: Hi, I would like to bring another draft of extending QUIC CID to your attention. See https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-shi-quic-structured-connection-id/

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
CSIG seems to have the network elements tag packets with new information at layer 2, which is eventually received by the end host and reflected back to the sender in TCP option or -- somehow -- in UDP.  This seems to require layer 2 to support CSIG from the network element doing CSIG to the host receiving the packet, as well as the host receiving the packet to pull that information from layer 2 header and hand to the (application?) stack to reflect in a TCP option (somehow; there aren't great APIs for doing that on iOS or Windows) or into UDP payload.  

Sorry, feels like a research project where all the parts can be controlled by someone wanting to build this idea.  Like a software-oriented datacenter.

I don't see it working on the Internet but perhaps I cannot think grand enough?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: @VMatrix1900, regarding draft-shi-quic-structured-connection-id, I have tons of questions.  How is Configuration Agent discovered by client, and how by server, how does configuration agent know which Intermediary to signal, who would operate the Configuration Agent (the client's [Wi-Fi] network? The subscriber's ISP? The server's network?  Any and all of those?).  Can there be multiple Intermediaries?  Overall, the network diagram feels like a Software Defined Network that emerged 10-15 years ago, and are still actively used, and which might be useful to leverage for such a system.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body:
> CSIG seems to have the network elements tag packets with new information at layer 2, which is eventually received by the end host and reflected back to the sender in TCP option or -- somehow -- in UDP. This seems to require layer 2 to support CSIG from the network element doing CSIG to the host receiving the packet, as well as the host receiving the packet to pull that information from layer 2 header and hand to the (application?) stack to reflect in a TCP option (somehow; there aren't great APIs for doing that on iOS or Windows) or into UDP payload.
> 
> Sorry, feels like a research project where all the parts can be controlled by someone wanting to build this idea. Like a software-oriented datacenter.
> 
> I don't see it working on the Internet but perhaps I cannot think grand enough?

CSIG is for Datacenter network in which the switch is used to modify the L2 tag. It can not work on the internet.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body:
> @VMatrix1900, regarding draft-shi-quic-structured-connection-id, I have tons of questions. How is Configuration Agent discovered by client, and how by server, how does configuration agent know which Intermediary to signal, who would operate the Configuration Agent (the client's [Wi-Fi] network? The subscriber's ISP? The server's network? Any and all of those?). Can there be multiple Intermediaries? Overall, the network diagram feels like a Software Defined Network that emerged 10-15 years ago, and are still actively used, and which might be useful to leverage for such a system.

The configuration agent is within the same domain as the intermediary. It is location depends on the usecase. In the media use case, the intermediary is the wireless node in the client access network. The configuration agent is the controller of the wireless nodes. In the QUIC-TE use case, the intermediary is in the server's network (Cloud WAN). The conguration agent is the controller of the Cloud WAN. It looks like SDN indeed.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> In the media use case, the intermediary is the wireless node in the client access network.  The configuration agent is the controller of the wireless nodes.

Which means the content server (let's say, "Facebook") communicates with the subscriber's Internet Service Provider.  Which means they have to authenticate each other, which means the ISP learns the identity of the content provider.  This means ESNI no longer hides the identity from the ISP (but ESNI would continue to hide the server's identity from other on-path devices, of course).

> In the QUIC-TE use case, the intermediary is in the server's network (Cloud WAN). The conguration agent is the controller of the Cloud WAN. 

Ok.  That model seems similar to draft-ietf-quic-load-balancers, but rather than controlling a load balancer you're controlling the WAN.

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body:
> > In the media use case, the intermediary is the wireless node in the client access network.  The configuration agent is the controller of the wireless nodes.
> 
> Which means the content server (let's say, "Facebook") communicates with the subscriber's Internet Service Provider. Which means they have to authenticate each other, which means the ISP learns the identity of the content provider. This means ESNI no longer hides the identity from the ISP (but ESNI would continue to hide the server's identity from other on-path devices, of course).

This is related to the business model. It does not necessarily reveal the content server identity. Let's say ISP provide media-aware QoS optimization service. It can issue an anoymous key to any content servers who purchase the service(think of a concert ticket which do not check the ID instead of flight ticket which is tied to ID). Then the intermediary can not differentiate between different content providers.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
> This is related to the business model. It does not necessarily reveal the content server identity. Let's say ISP provide media-aware QoS optimization service. It can issue an anoymous key to any content servers who purchase the service(think of a concert ticket which do not check the ID instead of flight ticket which is tied to ID). Then the intermediary can not differentiate between different content providers.

Sorry, I don't see how that would work.  ISP puts the key onto a publicly-available server at, let's say, https://www.t-mobile.com/key.txt, and all the content providers would use that key, and nobody would abuse it?  That can't be what you have in mind.  I only see a solution with some sort of authorization for Certain Special content providers to use that key.  And each content provider would be given its own key because unique keys are necessary for hygiene (key rotation and the eventual fallout of their contract and need to pull their key without disrupting service for other content providers).

(Is there a better place to have this discussion?)

comments.author: VMatrix1900
comments.body: @danwing I created [an issue](https://github.com/VMatrix1900/draft-quic-structured-connection-id/issues/1) in my repo. Let's continue dicussion there.

issues.title: metadata is not needed for each packet
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/blob/fc1c5d954810610bb9802f95868738c9217f638d/draft-wing-cidfi.md?plain=1#L150

I thought that I have modified this to cover cases where only a subset of packets are enriched, not all. Any reason why we have all to be so?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
You're right -- we don't need every CID mapped to metadata.  Also as written, that sentence implies the metadata is *in* the IP packet itself.  With CIDFI, that never occurs.  Rather, it's a mapping of CID to metadata.

And, yes, there is no reason to have every CID mapped to metadata.  Those would receive 'default' treatment (whatever that is).

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> You're right -- we don't need every CID mapped to metadata. Also as written, that sentence implies the metadata is _in_ the IP packet itself. With CIDFI, that never occurs. Rather, it's a mapping of CID to metadata.
> 
> And, yes, there is no reason to have every CID mapped to metadata. Those would receive 'default' treatment (whatever that is).

Agree. I trust you will change the text. Thanks.

comments.body: Fixed in #35

issues.title: Stream ID
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/blob/8e3eef44bd73ad95e96fc311fd447f53f21774cf/draft-wing-cidfi.md?plain=1#L581

We may consider defining a new QUIC frame, similar in processing to the DATAGRAM frame (but no user data is allowed inside). The frame can be sent in both directions h2n and n2h. No stream ID would be required then.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: Sounds like a great idea.  One note:  this communication is merely h2h, as no network element is involved -- although the data inside is intended to be relayed to the CIDFI Network Element.  I don't know how to express that in concise words, however.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: You are right that the frame is mainly between the ultimate endpoints of a communication.

issues.title: Packet type in Figure 6
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/blob/602c0125c6d257b180f7f9cd711a05d1be2a28ef/draft-wing-cidfi.md?plain=1#L672

Why is this an initial packet? This should be any QUIC packet with SCID=xyz + signaled 4-uple. No?

Also, why do we have an OK right after?

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
On Nov 22, 2023, at 1:42 AM, Med ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/blob/602c0125c6d257b180f7f9cd711a05d1be2a28ef/draft-wing-cidfi.md?plain=1#L672
Why is this an initial packet? This should be any QUIC packet with SCID=xyz + signaled 4-uple. No?Agreed, it could be a connection migration to this network.  But really we don’t need a QUIC exchange first; we can avoid showing that if it clarifies things to not show QUIC initial handshake. 
Also, why do we have an OK right after?The Ok shows the server supports CIDFI.  Now that the server is optional for CIDFI, we don’t need the Ok. -d

—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.body: Ok, let's then update the figure. Thanks.

issues.title: Direction
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/blob/602c0125c6d257b180f7f9cd711a05d1be2a28ef/draft-wing-cidfi.md?plain=1#L833C30-L833C34

"Map DCID=xyz as high importance": refers here to a CID chosen by the server not the DCID used by the server to communicate with the client (which is mirroring a CID picked by the client). 

May be worth clarifying in the text.

issues.title: Importance signal may be abused by some hosts
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: Details about how the signal is used by CNEs to enforce policies are worth discussing.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
I agree some text is needed.

My view is a client only influences traffic to itself, and CIDFI does not influence traffic to other clients.  A difficulty of course is where the network places NATs which obscure "other clients" because of IP address sharing but NAPT isn't CIDFI's fault.

issues.title: identify related packets
issues.author: danwing
issues.body:
Could/should we signal 'related' packets with certain CIDs, with the intent the network tries to deliver all or none of them.  For example a 3000 byte payload that needs to be split into 2-3 packets and is only useful if all packets are received.

This could be signaled as a bundle of CIDs which should are 'related', e.g., CID 123, 373, 673.  (Note the CIDs are still randomly-chosen and have no natural relationship to each other)

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: I'm afraid that the more we require sophisticated state handling, the more it will be challenging to convince the network operators to implement CIDFI.

comments.body: It is possible that the local network may not have CIDFI-aware network element but the ISP may have CIDFI-aware network element.  I suggest to replace "the client concludes that the local network does not support CIDFI" with "the client concludes the local network and ISP do not support CIDIF".
I don't think standardizing 3GPP PCO is in the scope of IETF. Why do we have to discuss about "3GPP PCO" ?

Agree we don't need to specify the PCO IE in this draft as this is a 3GPP thing. 

That's said, I think this is covered by "or some of these" in the text proposed by Dan. I think the current wording is OK here.

pulls.author: danwing

comments.author: danwing
comments.body:
@boucadair, while editing this I had a few questions:

For (1), what is a "proxied connection".  Is that a MASQUE-like thing?  Or CONNECT UDP?  Or what?

For (2), what is "out of band metadata sharing".  

For (2), I don't understand how there is optional metadata from client to "Network", but there is non-optional (?) metadata from Server to "Network".  The client is always involved in that signaling, but I think the diagram is showing the client has no metadata it would communicate to the "Network"?

For (2), I don't know if my change depicts "Glue CXs" properly because I couldn't figure out the intent of the original diagram.

For all of them, I suppose "Network" the CIDFI-aware Network Element, right?  I wasn't confident enough on that assumption to make the change.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
> @boucadair, while editing this I had a few questions:
> 
> For (1), what is a "proxied connection". Is that a MASQUE-like thing? Or CONNECT UDP? Or what?
> 

This can be MASQUE thing, 3GPP ATSSS, whatsoever. We don't need to call out how this is realized by what the external behavior looks like. 

> For (2), what is "out of band metadata sharing".
> 
> For (2), I don't understand how there is optional metadata from client to "Network", but there is non-optional (?) metadata from Server to "Network". The client is always involved in that signaling, but I think the diagram is showing the client has no metadata it would communicate to the "Network"?

(2) is actually mirroring existing practices marketed, e.g., as RAN-assisted acceleration and the like. The client is not involved in such schemes (to ease deployablity and lower dependency on UEs). Adding a client-network leg is an evolution to these schemes, and hence the "optional" tagging.

We may have a variant of (2) with both legs optional or mandatory, but I thought this would over-complexify the figure.

> 
> For (2), I don't know if my change depicts "Glue CXs" properly because I couldn't figure out the intent of the original diagram.
> 

Endpoints will need to correlate the signal with the main communication. Some means to glue the two sessions is thus required. Again we we don't need to explain how, but that is an extra feature at the server side compared to the use of the main communication to share data.

> For all of them, I suppose "Network" the CIDFI-aware Network Element, right? I wasn't confident enough on that assumption to make the change.

In practice yes, but we don't have "CIDFI-aware Network Element" introduced at this stage. The intent of the figure is to provide a macroscopic view before diving into CIDFI mechanic.

comments.author: danwing
comments.body: Thanks for explanation!

pulls.title: Update security considerations section and update text for clarity
pulls.author: tireddy2

comments.author: tireddy2
comments.body:
> > A valid HMAC can only be obtained by the attacker making its own connection to the CIDFI-aware server and spoofing the source IP address and UDP port number of the victim.
> 
> The attacker doesn't need the HMAC key -- they can just see the STUN packet with the HMAC output from the victim. So I'm not sure "only" in the original sentence is accurate. I would say it's the only way for the attacker to get the HMAC key. But obtaining the HMAC key is not the only way for the attacker to perform an attack on the STUN message.

Agreed, fixed text by removing "only".
Please add a pointer to where this is defined in RFC9000.

```suggestion
> Note: {{fig-import}} lists sample attributes and they will be discussed in detail in a separate document.
```

```suggestion
Spoofing Attacks:
: For an attacker to succeed with the nonce challenge against a victim's UDP 4-tuple, an attacker has to send a STUN CIDFI-NONCE packet using the victim's source IP address and a valid HMAC. A valid HMAC can only be obtained by the attacker making its own connection to the CIDFI-aware server and spoofing the source IP address and UDP port number of the victim.
: If the client does not support CIDFI, the attacker can influence the packet treatment of the victim's UDP 4-tuple.
: If the client implements CIDFI, a CIDFI network element can identify an IP address spoofing attack. Concretely, the CNE will receive two HTTPS connections describing the same DCID; one connection from the attacker and another one from the victim. The CNE will then issue unique Nonces and HMACs to both the attacker and victim, and both the attacker and victim should send the STUN Indication on that same UDP 4-tuple. Such an event should trigger an alarm on the CNE. In this scenario, it is recommended that both the attacker and the victim be denied CIDFI access.
: The spoofing of a victim's IP address is prevented by the network using network ingress filtering ({{!RFC2827}}, {{!RFC7513}}, {{!RFC6105}}, and/or {{!RFC6620}}).
```

```suggestion
On-Path Attacks:
: An on-path attacker can observe the victim's Discovery Packet, block it, and then forward the packet within the attacker's 5-tuple. Subsequently, the on-path attacker can 'steal' the victim's CIDFI control from the victim's UDP 4-tuple, causing the victim's CIDFI signaling for that UDP 4-tuple to influence the attacker's UDP 4-tuple.
: Although the on-path attacker can't directly observe the encrypted CIDFI signaling, this attack effectively disables the victim's CIDFI treatment, making it accessible to the attacker. The attacker can send NEW_CONNECTION_ID frames to the server with the victim's (observed) Destination CID, effectively claiming the victim's CIDFI signaling for themselves. To mitigate this replay attack, shared networks require per-endpoint encryption (e.g., Wi-Fi WPA3, DOCSIS BPI+) or traffic separation (e.g., Ethernet switching rather than bridging).
```

> The attacker can send NEW_CONNECTION_ID frames to the server with the..

But this will be rejected by the server.
A QUIC client is free to use use any DCID; multiple QUIC clients within the the same endpoint itself can use the same DCID.

My comment was about an attacker who sends a NEW_CONNECTION_ID. Adding or retiring CIDs is encrypted and thus don't see on which case an attacker can inject those and pass through the validation at the server side.

It is discussed in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc9000#section-8.1. It says "Additionally, an endpoint MAY consider the peer address validated if the peer uses a connection ID chosen by the endpoint and the connection ID contains at least 64 bits of entropy."
I meant the attacker can create a new QUIC connection using the same DCID.
Please cite that section in the text. Thanks

But if it creates a new connection, then the initial DCID will be set to zero. 

Also, how this interferes with the connection that was established by the client.

The on-path attacker creates a new QUIC connection with the same DCID as the victim to server, it drops the STUN indication message from client and sends STUN indication message to prove ownership of the 5-tuple. It means, the victim will not be able to prioritize packets. The connection from the victim will continue to exit.

I may be missing something, but I'm still having trouble with this part especially that the sentence right after says "To mitigate **this replay attack** .. Can you please share a simple drawing with the various messages? Thanks.
The relay attack mitigation is not applicable with a on-path attacker who is capable of dropping the traffic from victim. I will remove it.

Thanks for removing that part. 

Still need a figure with the various messages to digest the attack.

[cidfi-attack.pptx](https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/files/13437765/cidfi-attack.pptx)
Attached figure explaining the on-path attack.
Thanks. The file points to the generic cidfi prez.
[cidfi-attack.pptx](https://github.com/danwing/cidfi/files/13438288/cidfi-attack.pptx)
Please see the updated presentation.

reviews.author: danwing
reviews.body:
> A valid HMAC can only be obtained by the attacker making its own connection to the CIDFI-aware server and spoofing the source IP address and UDP port number of the victim.

The attacker doesn't need the HMAC key -- they can just see the STUN packet with the HMAC output from the victim.  So I'm not sure "only" in the original sentence is accurate.  I would say it's the only way for the attacker to get the HMAC key.  But obtaining the HMAC key is not the only way for the attacker to perform an attack on the STUN message.
